translated: Jātaka
Ten-&-Twelve
The Four Gates
The Jātaka of Kaṇhadīpāyana
“For seven days I was faithful,
Seeking merit, a spiritual teacher, a holy life;

analyzed: atha aparam yam caritam mama idam
translated: Then what I did after that,
For fifty-one years,
I went without desire,
By this truth may there be safety.
The poison is destroyed. May Yaññadatta live!”
“Because I never rejoiced in giving,
When I saw a guest at the time of lodging,

analyzed: na ca api me appiyatam avedu
translated: And because I did not show displeasure,
To the learned monks and brahmins.”
I gave without desire,
By this truth may there be safety.
The poison is destroyed. May Yaññadatta live!”
“Son, the many-splendored poisonous snake

analyzed: yaḥ tam adasī sacarāḥ udid ca
translated: Who bit you, rising up,

analyzed: tasmin ca me appiya tāya ajja
translated: And because I have no displeasure in him today,

original: Pitari ca te natthi koci viseso;
analyzed: pitari ca te natthi koci viseso
translated: And because you have no difference in your father,
By this truth may there be safety,
The poison is destroyed. May Yaññadatta live!”
“The self-controlled wanderers,
Apart from the black, there are no other forms.
Why, Dīpāyaṇa, are you disgusted?
Why do you live the spiritual life unwillingly?”

original: “Saddhāya nikkhamma punaṁ nivatto,🔽So eḷamūgova bālo vatāyaṁ;
analyzed: saddhāya nikkhamma punar nivattaḥ  saḥ eḷamūgā uva bālaḥ vatāya
translated: “Having gone forth through faith, I turned back again.🔽This fool is like a blind man.
Disgusted with his view,
I live the spiritual life unwillingly.
I will be one who is praised by the wise and the noble,

original: Evampahaṁ puññakaro bhavāmi”.🔽“Samaṇe tuvaṁ brāhmaṇe addhike ca,
analyzed: evampaham puñña karaḥ bhavāmi  samaṇe tuvam brāhmaṇe addhike ca
translated: And thus I will make merit.”
“You satisfy with food and drink the ascetics, brahmins, and beggars.
This house of yours is like a ford,
With food and drink ready to hand.
Why, then, are you disgusted with your view?
Why do you give this gift unwillingly?”

analyzed: pitaro ca me āsum pitāmahā ca
translated: “My fathers and forefathers
Were faithful, generous, and givers of gifts.
Following in their footsteps,

analyzed: mā aham kule antima gandhanaḥ ahu
translated: I don’t want to be the last in the family to have a bad smell.
Disgusted with this view,
I give this gift unwillingly.”
“A young girl, a child, with little wisdom,

analyzed: yam tānayim ñāti kulā su gatte
translated: In the family of my relatives, in the happy state,

analyzed: na ca api me appiyatam avedi
translated: Nor did they ever show me any dislike,
Except in the matter of their sexual desires.

original: Atha kena vaṇṇena mayā te bhoti,
analyzed: atha kena vaṇṇena mayā te bhoti
translated: But what reason have you, Sir,
For such a conduct as this?”
“There is no such thing as a distant kinsman here,
In this family it is a matter of succession;
Following the custom of the family,

analyzed: mā aham kule antima gandhinī ahu
translated: I did not wish to be the last of the family to die out;
Disgusted with this talk,
I have come to you unwillingly.”
“You have spoken well, O Maṇḍabya, what should be spoken,
For the sake of your son I forgive you;

analyzed: putta pemā na idha paratthi kiñci
translated: There is nothing here or in the next world that is dearer than a son,
This Yajñadatta is our life.”
The Kaṇhadīpāyana Jātaka is the sixth.
